I forgot to say, there's nothing special needed to build nsync with bazel. bazel test :all should work to build and test both with a C and a C++11 build.
…
On 23 October 2017 at 11:57, Mike Burrows ***@***.***> wrote: Assuming you wish to build nsync as C++11 (which is what TensorFlow requires), at the root of the nsync tree do: cp -r builds/x86_64.linux.c++11 builds/s390x.linux.c++11 cd builds/s390x.linux.c++11 make depend test This doesn't actually use the new header file because it's using C++11 atomics. To try the new header file, do a C build, like this: mkdir builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc sed 's,x86_64,s390x,g' builds/x86_64.linux.old_gcc/Makefile > builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc/Makefile touch builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc/dependfile cd builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc make depend test This will build nsync as C (not C++11) using "old-style" gcc atomics; that will use the header file. (Old-style gcc atomics have compare and swap, but don't include loads and stores, so those are implemented with ordinary loads and stores, with extra memory barriers as indicated by the flag in the new header. The assumption here is that the platform will perform loads and stores atomically if they are 32-bits and naturally aligned. New-style gcc atomics do include loads and stores, and so again wouldn't really need the header file.) As you can tell, there are a distressingly large number of options for getting atomic operations, because some platforms implement some techniques, while others implement different ones. I forgot to say, there's nothing special needed to build nsync with bazel.
   bazel test :all
should work to build and test both with a C and a C++11 build.
…
On 23 October 2017 at 11:57, Mike Burrows ***@***.***> wrote:
 Assuming you wish to build nsync as C++11
 (which is what TensorFlow requires), at the root of the nsync tree do:
   cp -r builds/x86_64.linux.c++11 builds/s390x.linux.c++11
   cd builds/s390x.linux.c++11
   make depend test
 This doesn't actually use the new header file because it's using C++11
 atomics.

 To try the new header file, do a C build, like this:
     mkdir builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc
     sed 's,x86_64,s390x,g' builds/x86_64.linux.old_gcc/Makefile >
 builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc/Makefile
     touch builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc/dependfile
     cd builds/s390x.linux.old_gcc
     make depend test
 This will build nsync as C (not C++11)
 using "old-style" gcc atomics; that will use the header file.
 (Old-style gcc atomics have compare and swap, but
 don't include loads and stores, so those are
 implemented with ordinary loads and stores, with extra memory barriers
 as indicated by the flag in the new header.   The assumption here is
 that the platform will perform loads and stores atomically if
 they are 32-bits and naturally aligned.
 New-style gcc atomics do include loads and stores, and so again wouldn't
 really need
 the header file.)

 As you can tell, there are a distressingly large number of
 options for getting atomic operations, because some platforms
 implement some techniques, while others implement different ones.
